reviewText: This film mesmerized me with its eerie sound effects and intense performances. A film Russian in its elemental humanity, German in its expressionist mis-en-scene. It's loud, even when it whispers. That the film itself haunts seems appropriate given that it is a ghost-story of sorts. If you're just looking for entertainment, look elsewhere. This is a film about ultimate questions.The transfer looks okay on analogue television, but on my laptop it lacks definition, as if it were transfered from a second-rate VHS tape. Wish the folks at Criterion would get their hands on this one. I would not hesitate to upgrade.If you like stately and intensely reflective films about the interior of the soul, by all means RENT this.
summary: The Letter and the Spirit of Dostoevsky

reviewText: I was lucky to find an acutal Russian movie version of 'Crime and Punishment'.  It was made in the 70s, but is in black and white.  The directors and producers have done a fine job here in staying faithful to the book and going into the mind of the main character.  It was the very psychological book and so is the movie.  The movie is not as sad as the book though because very few people could duplicate Foydor's mastery.  Read the book and then watch this movie (if you can find it).
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Atmosphere" isn't enough in a cinematic transcription of Dostoevsky's great philosophical/political novel, but it's all you get in this four-hour black-and-gray snoozer. I'm astonished that other reviewers have praised it. I ordered it on their recommendations, but never have I been so disappointed. There is not a single indication in this film of Raskolnikov's thinking before his crime, or of the intellectual ferment in mid-19th C Russia, the potting soil from which C&P; sprouted. Even Dostoevsky's religious message is cast aside in the film-maker's lugubrious effort to include every bit of the "story" without even a hint of the ideas.There's also a problem with the technology. If you choose the English dubbing rather than the original Russian with English subtitles, the film flip-flops from English to Russian every three or four 'chapters'. If you choose Russian over dubbed English, and depend on the subtitles, you'll find it hard to read them fast enough while also keeping an eye on the actors. It's a botched job of editing all around. Skip it. Read the book, and if you read it years ago, read it again.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Among the adapted versions translated to screen this is perhaps, the most successful. This classic story deals about an impoverished student living In a rooming house who decides to murder an old pawnbroker.No matter how many times you have watched or read this brutal story. This novel was the true pivot, the great gate to the existentialist movement. Think for instance in Dostoievsky's prodigal son; Albert Camus and the Happy death: you will find similar traces.This Russian adaptation maintains the mystery and sinister poetry, where all the centuries of Czarists oppression would seem emerge with all the potency of a volcanic eruption.Filmed in glorious black and white to accent the climax.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a review of the 3-DVD, 4-hour-long, black & white, Soviet-era (1970) mini-series based on Dostoyevsky's novel "Crime and Punishment." This is a great film; if you enjoy great literature, you should watch it.Fyodor Mikhaylovich Dostoyevsky is my favorite writer. He is (arguably) without peer. No other writer matches Dostoyevky's talent for creating vivid, fascinating, realistic, diverse, passionate, tormented, complex, and self-contradictory characters. I re-read the novel immediately before watching this film. This mini-series is admirably faithful to the novel; it is far superior to any other film adaptation.I was very impressed with this film. Principle actors Georgi Taratorkin (as Raskolnikov) and Tatyana Bedova (as Sonya) are ideal for their rolls. All other actors gave great performances. Consistent with the limitations of the medium and the budget, dialogue, character positions, movements within a scene, settings, and costumes match the novel well. I was particularly impressed with the way the film conveyed the internal thoughts of the main character (Raskolnikov). I am in awe of the director for successfully doing this.The English sub-titles are excellent. Many modern Russian films apparently use computer-translations, resulting in gross (often comical) sub-titles. The sub-titles in "Crime and Punishment" are quite accurate. As other reviewers have stated, sometimes the sub-titles are difficult to read due to poor contrast between the letters and the background.Mini-series have also been made of two other Dostoyevsky novels: Brothers Karamazov and Idiot (Bratya Karamazovy / The Brothers Karamazov [DVD NTSC][ENGLISH SUBTITLES][2009] andThe Idiot (4 DVD Set)). I highly recommend both of these mini-series.
summary: The best film adaptation of "Crime and Punishment"
